article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on Hydroelasticity Theories and Applications

abstract.p: To provide guidance on structural design for the life cycle safety of an ultra-large 500,000 deadweight tonnage ore carrier, the springing-induced high-frequency responses in waves, the resultant structural loads and their influences on the structural fatigue damage were investigated by employing the three-dimensional linear and second-order non-linear hydroelasticity theories of ships and the corresponding numerical methods. The theoretical predictions of the structural loads and responses and the comparisons with the model tests carried out in the towing tank of the China Ship Scientific Research Center are presented in this paper. The results for the hydroelastic responses of the ship at a forward speed and at zero forward speed in regular and irregular waves are illustrated, which provide the quantitative relations for the wave-motion-induced and the springing-induced structural loads, and their linear and non-linear components of the ship in different sea states, especially when the first flexible body resonant frequency is in the wave frequency region. The results show that the springing responses may occur in waves with any significant wave heights for such a large ship when the characteristic wave periods are less than a certain amount. The short-term and long-term distributions of the wave-induced and rigid-body-motion-induced structural loads and the springing-induced high-frequency loads are predicted. Based on the hydroelastic predictions of the structural loads, the accumulated fatigue theory is applied to assess the fatigue damage of the typical deck and bottom structural components of a ship serving in three shipping lines.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The steady growth of the economy in the People’s Republic of China requires an increasing supply of ore and energy resources. This has led to the design and investigation of a 500,000 deadweight tonnage (DWT) ultra-large ore carrier in the People’s Republic of China. In the same way the maximum dimensions of newly built bulk carriers, containers and tankers have greatly increased during the past few decades in the world because of the growing demand for sea transportation. When a large or an ultra-large ship is travelling in waves, the springing and whipping responses appear to happen more frequently, even in waves of sea states which were not regarded as severe before. For weight reduction, more high-strength steel plates have been used in ship hulls, leading to a reduction in the structural rigidity and an increasing possibility of fatigue damage. Therefore the influence of high-frequency springing and whipping responses on the structural safety has attracted great attention from naval architects and ship owners. For more than 20 years, model tests, theoretical analyses and full-scale measurements have been carried out to investigate the springing phenomena and to develop practical prediction methods.1–15 It has been reported that the springing responses may apparently increase the wave bending moments and structural fatigue damage of large oil tankers, container ships and bulk carriers, as shown in Table 1. However, the influence of springing and whipping on the ultimate strength and fatigue damage of ship structures has not yet been included in the design rules. This requires further investigations on the mechanism of springing behaviours of large and ultra-large ships, and also on the development of practical prediction methods, among which hydroelastic analysis methods are evidently of great importance.

caption.p: The springing-induced increases in the bending moment and the structural fatigue damage.

sec.p: During the past two decades, linear three-dimensional (3D) hydroelasticity theories11–18 have been applied to different kinds of ships and marine structures. The non-linear hydroelasticity theory proposed by Wu et al.19 and the numerical method developed by Tian20 have been used to predict the wave loads and springing behaviour of a 180,000 DWT large bulk carrier15 and revealed that the contribution of the second-order components to the total springing bending moment could be as high as 28% in magnitude when the ship is travelling in head irregular waves of sea state 5 at a design speed of 15 kn.

For a ship as large as the 500,000 DWT ore carrier, the two-node bending response appears all the time in irregular waves with a relatively small characteristic wave period. It is then difficult to distinguish between the ‘wave-induced’ and ‘springing-induced’ loads and responses on the basis of the traditional concept. It is clear that the structural safety can not be assessed without performing a hydroelastic analysis. In this paper, the linear and non-linear 3D hydroelastic analysis results of this 500,000 DWT ultra-large ore carrier are presented and discussed. Both the linear and the non-linear predictions exhibited the springing behaviours and the frequency characteristics of the dynamic responses of the ship at a forward speed and at zero forward speed in regular and irregular waves. The structural loads and their short-term significant values in irregular waves of different sea states were predicted when the ship was stationary at zero forward speed and for different wave headings, or when travelling at 15 kn in the head direction. The theoretical predictions were compared with the results of model tests carried out in the towing tank at the China Ship Scientific Research Center (CSSRC) and achieved fairly good agreement, showing that the prediction methods may be used to examine properly the springing responses and high-frequency loads.

Based on the hydroelastic analyses, short-term and long-term fatigue damage assessment of the ship structure was performed. This showed that, when this ultra-large ship is travelling in the full-load condition in the course lines A (China–Brazil), B (China–Africa) and C (China–Australia), the springing-induced fatigue damage of a deck stiffener and that of a bottom stiffener could reach about 52–78% of the total fatigue damage.

sec.title: Numerical methods
sec.p: The 3D hydroelastic responses of a ship travelling in waves are calculated by employing the code THAFTS, which is based on a fast algorithm for calculating the Bessho form translating–pulsating source Green’s function and its derivatives,21 and a desingularized source distribution method with a Galerkin technique to calculate the 3D non-uniform steady flow potential and its high-order derivatives.23 This program package allows all the terms appearing in the linear 3D hydroelasticity theory to be retained in the numerical analysis, as described in the section on the linear hydroelasticity theory. The second-order non-linear 3D hydroelastic analysis described in the section on the non-linear hydroelasticity theory is performed by using the code NTHAFTS.20 This provides the possibility of predicting both the first-order and the second-order hydroelastic responses of a ship travelling in rough seas at a forward speed.

sec.title: The test model
sec.p: A segmented model with the scale of 1:73.5 of the 500,000 DWT ultra-large ore carrier made of glass-fibre-reinforced plastics with wood frames was tested in the towing tank of CSSRC.27,28 The principal particulars of the ship are listed in Table 2. The model was divided into nine segments with two longitudinal backbones linking the segments at a position under the deck, as shown in Figure 1. The strain gauges M1 to M8 were used to measure the wave-induced bending moments and the acceleration transducers A1 to A3 were employed to determine the heave and pitch motions. Table 3 provides the model test results and predictions of the resonant frequencies of the ship in water.

sec.title: Tests in regular waves
sec.p: The regular-wave tests in head seas were carried out to measure the transfer functions of the vertical bending moment (VBM). Figures 2 and 3 exhibit the measured wave elevation and the measured VBM at the midship section M4 of the model travelling at U = 0.9 m/s (15 kn on a full scale) in regular waves of frequency ω0 = 4.44 rad/s and encounter frequency ωe = 6.25 rad/s. The wave amplitude was 60 mm, corresponding to 4.4 m on a full scale. Except for the component of the VBM due to the encounter wave frequency (WM), the measured time variation (Figure 3) of the total VBM (CM) at the midship section M4 contains a high-frequency component corresponding to the two-node bending mode of the segmented model. This clearly shows the springing phenomenon, which makes the amplitude of the total VBM doubled with regard to the component of the encounter wave frequency. Since the resonant frequency of the two-node bending mode is only almost three times the encounter wave frequency in this case, severe springing is naturally expected. No slamming and whipping were found in this wave condition. Figure 4 exhibits the fast Fourier transformations of the midship VBMs of the model with the forward speeds 0 m/s and 0.9 m/s respectively. Evidently, when U = 0, the first peak at ω0 = 4.44 rad/s corresponds to the wave-induced VBM and dominates the response. The other three small peaks are respectively the responses at 2ω0, 3ω0 and the two-node bending resonant frequency. When U = 0.9, the first peak at 6.25 rad/s is the encounter-wave-induced VBM and the second peak at 18.6 rad/s shows the springing-induced VBM with an amplitude apparently greater than the wave-induced VBM.

sec.p: It was also found that, when 2a = 85 mm, λ/L = 0.3 and U = 0.9 m/s, not only did springing appear continuously, but also whipping occurred repeatedly. In regular wave responses due to the small damping and slow decay of the whipping response, it was hard to separate the springing-induced and whipping-induced bending moments precisely. For this kind of ship, the separation method is a new challenge and will not be discussed in this paper.

sec.title: Tests in irregular waves
sec.p: The model was also tested with a heading angle of 180° in three typical irregular sea states C01, C02A and C03 described by the Pierson–Moskowitz (P–M) wave spectra corresponding to a full-scale significant wave height from 2.65 m to 5.92 m and a characteristic wave period from 6.45 s to 10.71 s, as shown in Table 5. The forward speed was 0.9 m/s (15 kn on a full scale). Although not tested, the sea state C02B is also listed in Table 5, which has the same characteristic wave period as C02A but a higher significant wave height like C03 and is used in numerical predictions to examine the influences of the wave height and the period on the non-linear effects and springing responses.

sec.p: Figure 6 exhibits the test results of the encounter waves and the VBMs at the midship section M4 and the stern section M1 of the model in the full-load condition travelling at 0.9 m/s in the sea states C01, C02A and C03. No slamming and whipping events were observed during the tests. The peaks appearing in the figures correspond to the responses at the resonant frequencies of the pitch mode (about 2.9 rad/s), heave mode (about 4.3 rad/s), two-node bending mode (19 rad/s), three-node bending mode (about 43 rad/s) and four-node bending mode (about 70 rad/s), as well as at the peak frequencies of the wave spectra. To show clearly the correspondence of the peaks to the resonant frequencies of the structure in water the frequency abscissae of Figure 6 are dimensional.

caption.p: Variation in the VBMs with regard to the encounter wave frequency at the midship section M4 and the stern section M1 of the model in the full-load condition in irregular waves at a forward speed U = 0.9 m/s: (a) sea state C01; (b) sea state C02A; (c) sea state C03.

sec.p: For such a large ship the two-node bending resonant frequency evidently falls in the wave frequency range of these sea states. This makes it difficult to identify and distinguish quantitatively the wave-induced and the springing-induced components contained in the measured total VBM. Hence the zero-crossing method was used to identify the amplitudes of wave crests and valleys within the major encounter wave period and hence to account for the statistical parameters. To obtain sufficient samplings for statistical analyses of the motion responses and bending moments, the measurement duration for each wave condition was longer than a period corresponding to 1 h of the full-scale trail.

Figure 6 shows that the springing-induced two-node VBMs at the midship section are greater than the wave-induced and motion-induced VBMs in sea states C01 and C02A; however, they are smaller in sea state C03, depending on the characteristic wave period. At the stern section M1 the springing-induced bending moments apparently contain the components of the three-node and four-node bending modes.

sec.title: Hydroelastic responses of the ultra-large ore carrier
sec.p: The dry structure of the 500,000 DWT ore carrier was simplified as a Timoshenko beam in the predictions of global loads and responses, while the ship’s 3D wetted surface was represented by 1000 panels (Figure 7). The dry modes calculated for the hydroelastic analyses include six rigid body modes, three vertical bending modes, two horizontal bending modes and two torsional modes. The corresponding natural and resonant frequencies of the vertical bending modes are shown in Table 3.

caption.p: The discretized wetted surface of the ore carrier.

sec.title: Linear hydroelastic responses of the ship in waves with zero forward speed
sec.p: The predicted response amplitude operators (RAOs) of the principal coordinates of the heave mode, the pitch mode and two vertical bending modes of the ship in regular head waves with unit amplitudes are shown in Figure 8. The model test results of the rigid body motions are also plotted in Figure 8(a) and (b), fitting with the predictions reasonably well. Figure 9 is the hammer test result of the midship bending moment of the model in calm water, showing the resonant frequencies. The comparison of the predicted and the measured resonant frequencies of the rigid body modes and the vertical bending modes is listed in Table 3. Good agreement was achieved with maximum discrepancies of less than 7%, except for the four-node bending mode. The model has only nine segments; hence the measured resonant frequency of the four-node bending mode could not represent the continuous mathematical model and is ignored in the present paper.

The hammer test results of the vertical bending response of the model in calm water.

sec.p: The present direct design guidelines29 require the direct strength analysis of a ship to be performed for the case of zero forward speed. Hence, in this section, the short-term and long-term predictions of wave loads of the ultra-large ore carrier at zero forward speed are briefly illustrated. The short-term predictions were carried out on the basis of the RAOs of VBMs obtained by 3D hydroelastic analyses. To include the influence of the wave heading angles in the wave load statistical analyses, the irregular waves were described by P–M wave spectra, and the RAOs of the midship VBMs were calculated for 24 different heading angles from 0° to 360° with angular differences of 15°, all at zero speed. Figure 10 shows the results.

caption.p: RAOs of the VBMs at the midship section of the ship at zero speed with different heading angles: (a) heading angles, 0° and 180°; (b) heading angles, 30° and 150°; (c) heading angles, 60° and 120°; (d) heading angles, 90° and 180°.

sec.p: Figure 11 exhibits the short-term predictions of the significant values of the midship VBMs with regard to the heading angles of the ship at zero speed in the sea state Hs = 4.0 m, T2 = 8.5 s. In the following figures, WM denotes the wave-induced and rigid-body-motion-induced low-frequency components of the VBM, and CM represents the total VBM, including the WM and the springing-induced components. WM is obtained by low-pass filtering of the VBM signal, disregarding the high-frequency components around and higher than the two-node bending resonant frequency.

caption.p: The variation in the midship VBM with regard to the wave heading angles in the short-term prediction (Hs = 4.0 m; T2 = 8.5 s).
WM: low-frequency component of the vertical bending moment; CM: total vertical bending moment.

sec.p: The WM values predicted by employing DNV Wasim Sesam30 are also plotted in the figure. The present predictions and the Wasim prediction show similar tendencies of the heading angle dependence. However, the latter is much larger for heading angles less than 100°. The cause of the discrepancy needs to be further clarified.

The long-term prediction values of the midship bending moments may be calculated once the wave distribution is prescribed. To examine the dependence of the long-term prediction value of the midship VBM on its probability of exceedance p described by equation (24), the global wave distribution recommended by the International Association of Classification Societies Ltd (IACS),31 as shown later in Table 8, was used. In the calculation the ship was stationary (U = 0) with 24 wave heading angles from 0° to 360° in waves described by the P–M wave spectra. The heading angles were uniformly distributed in probability. The result is shown in Figure 12. When the probability of exceedance p is 10–8, the corresponding long-term prediction value of the midship VBM would be 18,400 MN m. The average value of the sagging and the hogging bending moments roughly estimated by employing the IACS URS 11 formula32 was 19,400 MN m, about 10% higher than the present prediction for this ultra-large ore carrier.

sec.title: Linear and non-linear hydroelastic responses of the ship travelling at 15 kn
The RAOs of the hydroelastic responses
sec.p: The linear and non-linear hydroelastic responses of the ship travelling at 15 kn with 24 heading angles in regular and irregular waves were predicted by employing the methods described in the section on numerical methods and the section on the short-term and long-term prediction approach.

The available results of model tests in the towing tank were for the head sea case. Hence, in Figure 13, only the linear solutions of the RAOs of the midship VBMs of the ship in head regular waves at a forward speed of 15 kn are compared with the model test results. Good agreement was achieved, except that the test results cover only the frequency range less than ωL/g<5.9 owing to the limitation that the minimum regular wavelength which the towing tank may produce is about 1 m, corresponding to the full-scale wave frequency of 0.916 rad/s and the non-dimensional encounter wave frequency of 10.2 rad/s.

caption.p: RAO of the VBMs at the midship section of the ship travelling at 15 kn (β = 180°).

sec.title: The responses in irregular waves
sec.p: The hydroelastic responses in irregular waves were calculated for the four sea states defined in Table 5. The irregular-wave tests were carried out in the towing tank just before the wave-making system was maintained and improved. Figure 6 shows that the wave frequency spectra have small humps. Although the significant wave heights and the characteristic wave periods were almost the same as prescribed, the patterns of the frequency spectra and the power spectra were different and the peak frequencies did not agree well with those of the theoretical P–M wave spectra. In fact, in some cases the exceptional humps and the shift of peak frequencies of the wave spectra may cause differences in the springing predictions. For example, in sea state C01, the dominant encounter wave frequencies are within the frequency range 10–20 rad/s, covering the resonant frequency of the two-node vertical bending mode (about 18 rad/s). The different peak frequencies of the wave spectra greatly influenced the differences between the predictions and the test results of the springing bending moments. Therefore in the following calculations the measured wave spectra for the sea states C01, C02A and C03 were used instead of the spectra described by the P–M wave spectrum formula. The wave spectrum of sea state C02B was proportionally obtained from the test wave spectrum of sea state C02A.

Figures 14 and 15 exhibit time histories of the linear predictions and the non-linear predictions respectively of the combined (total) midship VBMs (CM) (dotted lines) and its wave-induced and rigid-body-motion induced components (WM) (solid curves) of the ship travelling at 15 kn in head irregular waves. The significant values of the linear and the non-linear predictions of CM are compared with the model test results in Table 6. The comparisons between the wave-induced and springing-induced significant midship VBMs, i.e. the WM and CM values, are listed in Table 7.

sec.p: The following phenomena may be observed.

list-item.p: In comparison with the test results, the linear and the non-linear predictions of the midship CM are about 1.8–13.6% higher in sea states C01 and C02A, providing reasonable results, but about 25–30% lower in sea state C03.

The increase in the significant wave heights between sea states C01 (2.65 m), C02A (3.64 m) and C02B (5.92 m) leads to the increase in the midship bending moments (CM) of about 60–65% in the linear predictions and 63–67% in the non-linear predictions. The corresponding increase in the model tests is even larger, about 76%. In these sea states the dominant wave frequencies are greater than 1 rad/s (wavelengths less than 60 m), with noticeable wave energy spreading over the two-node vertical bending resonant frequency of the hull (2 rad/s). Correspondingly the springing effects, represented by (CM−WM)/CM in Table 7, are within 23 – 35% in the linear predictions, 25–36% in the non-linear predictions and 43–46% in the model tests. This indicates that the springing responses are severe for the ultra-large ore carrier in waves with T2 = 6.45 s and T2 = 7.69 s on a full scale.

When the significant wave heights are kept the same, while the characteristic wave periods became longer from sea state C02B (7.69 s) to sea state C03 (10.71 s), the significant values of CM increased by about 110%. This is because in sea state C03 the dominant wave frequencies are less than 0.6 rad/s and the dominant wavelengths are longer than 160 m, resulting in greater interactions between waves and motions than in the much shorter waves of sea states C01 and C02A. Although the predicted springing response is small, and its contribution to the CM value is only about 2.4%, the wave-induced and motion-induced VBMs (WM) become significantly larger. The test results of sea state C03 also provided nearly the same WM value as the non-linear prediction. This is obviously reasonable. However, the test results showed a much larger CM value and a greater springing response than the predictions did. The reason for this requires further examination.

Although the significant values of CM and WM all become larger when the wave height increases, the non-linear effects, represented by (CMnon − CMlin)/CMnon as shown in Table 7, are all no more than 6% in the four sea states; neither the springing effects (CMlin − WMlin)/CMlin nor (CMnon − WMnon)/CMnon become larger with increase in the wave height. This is because the responses depend not only on the wave height but also on the wave period, as is discussed further in the next section.

For such a large ship with small rigid body motions, the non-linear excitations mainly arise from the instantaneous wetted surface effect, while the major source inducing the springing response is the coincidence of the frequency component contained in the hydrodynamic pressure acting over the whole wetted surface with the resonant frequency of the two-node bending mode of the hull. Hence the stronger (or weaker) non-linear effect does not necessarily lead to greater (or smaller) springing responses, and vice versa.

sec.p: Figure 16 shows the influence of the characteristic wave period T2 on the significant values of WM and CM in the midship section on a full scale. In this comparison it is assumed that Hs = 4.5 m/s for all characteristic wave periods. It shows that the springing responses, which are represented by the differences between the significant values of WM and CM, appear to be more severe when the characteristic wave period tends to be shorter and less than 7.5 s.

sec.p: The non-linear predictions of WM and CM take into account the instantaneous wetted surface effect and have non-linear behaviours with regard to the significant wave height and the characteristic wave period. Their difference represents the springing-induced value of VBM, which depends on Hs and T2 in a more complicated manner and will not be discussed in this paper.

sec.title: Fatigue strength assessment
sec.p: In the assessment of the structural fatigue damage of the ultra-large ore carrier, the hydroelastic responses of the ship were first calculated for a set of sea states used to represent long-term environmental conditions. The statistical data on VBMs (the WM and CM values) at the midship cross-sections of the ship hull were analysed for all sea states to obtain the effective fatigue loads. The Palmgren–Miner rule and the S–N curve for the typical structure form at the cross-section were employed to assess the short-term fatigue damage for each sea state. Based on the short-term forecasts covering all the required sea states, the long-term fatigue damage was assessed for the prescribed shipping lines and the wave conditions in the corresponding ocean zones.

In a complete and detailed fatigue assessment, the structural loads should include not only the wave-induced global loads but also the local wave pressure acting on the plates of the hull, the internal forces and the pressure due to the dry and liquid cargoes contained in the holds. However, in the present work, only those relevant to the vertical rigid body motions and the vertical bending responses of the ship in service were included in the structural fatigue assessment and hence the hydroelastic analyses. The horizontal bending and torsional moments were also neglected. The reasons are as follows.

list-item.p: Generally speaking, if the modal superposition of the dry structure of the ship includes all the global and the local modes, the hydroelastic analysis could provide an estimation of stresses at the hot spots induced not only by the global distortions (bending and torque) but also by the local deflections partly caused by the hydrodynamic pressures acting on the outer plates of the hull. This is because the hydrodynamic pressures of the incident, diffracted and radiation waves over the mean wetted surface are all contained in the response solutions. However, to include sufficient modes related to local deflections requires detailed structure modelling and greater computational effort. This can be carried out only when the detailed design of the ship structure is finalized and available for analysis. Hence only the global beam modes were employed in the analysis.
On the other hand, the global loads and distortions usually provide the most important fatigue loads.
The present simplification was used just for investigation of the methodology. It is a similar procedure to include other components of the global loads in the analysis.

The simplest way of dealing with the dry cargo loads is to treat them as an inertial mass. However, estimation of the dynamic-movement-induced loadings of dry and liquid cargoes needs more additional methods to be incorporated in the hydroelastic analysis.

sec.p: A typical stiffener of the main deck 1 (A in Figure 18) and a typical stiffener of the bottom structure 2 (B in Figure 18) at the midship section of the 500,000 DWT ultra-large ore carrier are taken as examples to illustrate the fatigue assessment method based on the hydroelastic analysis.

sec.p: It shows that the amounts of fatigue damage induced by WM and CM are quite different. At the worst the fatigue damage induced by CM could be 4.5 times the fatigue damage induced by WM. In the course line A the fatigue damage induced by WM is larger than those in the course lines B and C, just because the waves in this course line contain more long-period and high-amplitude components than do the other two courses. In course line B the occurrence of short-period waves has a higher probability, leading to relatively more severe springing responses and higher CM-induced fatigue damage. When this ship is travelling in the full-load condition in the three course lines the springing-induced fatigue damage of deck stiffener 1 and that of bottom stiffener 2 could reach about 52–78% of the total fatigue damage in its life cycle.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: Linear and non-linear 3D hydroelastic analysis methods were used to predict the short-term and long-term wave-induced and springing-induced loads, the responses and the cumulative fatigue damage of a 500,000 DWT ultra-large ore carrier. Model tests in regular and irregular waves with a heading angle of 180° were also carried out and the results were used for comparisons. The following conclusions may be drawn.

list-item.p: The hydroelastic analysis methods together with the short-term and long-term prediction procedures as described in this paper may be used to calculate directly the wave-induced and springing-induced loads, the structural responses and the fatigue damage of a ship travelling in regular and irregular waves with reasonable results.

The resonant frequency of the two-node vertical banding mode of a 500,000 DWT ultra-large ore carrier in water is around 0.3 Hz, or 2 rad/s. This is just in the wave frequency range of usual sea states and makes the wave-induced loads closely overlapped with the springing-induced loads in the frequency domain. In this case the hydroelastic analyses are obviously important and useful in load prediction and structural safety assessment.

The linear solutions of the RAOs and wave responses of the principal coordinates, rigid body motions and structural loads of the ultra-large ore carrier are well predicted and explained the frequency characteristics and the dynamic behaviours of the ship at a forward speed and at zero speed in regular and irregular waves. The comparisons between the linear predictions and the model test results of RAOs achieved good agreement. It shows that the springing responses may occur in waves with any significant wave heights for such a large ship when the characteristic wave periods are less than a certain amount. For example, when the characteristic wave period is 8.5 s, the springing-induced significant value of the midship VBM can be about 20.8% higher than that induced by only wave and rigid body motions at any significant wave height.

The linear and non-linear predictions in the sea states with shorter characteristic wave periods (T2 = 6.45 s and 7.69 s) provided significant values of the midship VBM only about 1.8–13.6% higher than the model test results. However, in the sea state with long wave periods (T2 = 10.71 s), both linear and non-linear predictions underestimated the VBM by about 25–30% in comparison with the model tests. The reason needs to be further clarified. The mechanism of the non-linear effect and the springing responses are discussed in the paper. It shows that in short-term predictions the relations between the wave conditions (the wave height and the wave period), the springing responses and the non-linear effects do not have a monotonic dependence and need to be examined individually and carefully, especially for an ultra-large and flexible ship.

Based on the hydroelastic analyses, short-term and long-term fatigue damage assessment of the ship structure may be performed. This paper only provides an example to exhibit the feasibility of this approach. It shows that, when this ultra-large ship is travelling in the full-load condition in three course lines (China–Brazil, China–Africa and China–Australia), the springing-induced fatigue damage of a deck stiffener and that of a bottom stiffener could reach about 52–78% of the total fatigue damage in a design life cycle of 25 years.

Finally, it should be mentioned that, for such a large ship, how to deal with the experimental data, to distinguish precisely, according to the traditional concept, the wave-induced and the springing-induced responses and loads (VBM, as a part) is still a problem seeking a more efficient approach.
